title: Sewing — Running Stitch on Felt
description: The child learns the running stitch, the foundational sewing stitch, using a blunt needle and felt fabric. This begins a multi-session sewing project that will culminate in creating a felt pouch or simple stuffed shape.
instructions:
1. 'Today we learn to SEW! Sewing is how people make clothes, blankets, and bags. We start with the running stitch.'
2. Show materials: felt square, blunt needle, embroidery thread.
3. Demonstrate threading the needle (with help). Tie a knot at the end of the thread.
4. 'The running stitch goes UP through the fabric, then DOWN, then UP again — like a dolphin swimming!' Demonstrate 3-4 stitches.
5. 'Keep your stitches even — try to make them all the same size.'
6. The child practices a line of running stitches across the felt.
7. 'When you reach the end, tie a knot on the back to secure it.'
materials_needed: Felt squares (2 pieces in different colors)

slides.heading: Sewing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to learn something super fun today called sewing! It's like drawing with a needle and thread to make cool things.

slides.setup_instructions: Cut felt into manageable squares (6x6 inches). Thread the needle with about 18 inches of thread. Tie a knot at one end. Optionally, draw a dotted line on the felt for the child to follow.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for sewing! We have soft felt, a special needle that's safe for us, and colorful thread. We also have scissors to cut and maybe a special pencil. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these things so we can start!

slides.text: 'People have been sewing for thousands of years — making clothes, blankets, bags, and beautiful decorations. Today you learn the most important stitch: the RUNNING STITCH!'
slides.mascot_explanation: People have been sewing for a super, super long time to make all sorts of things like clothes and cozy blankets. Today, we get to learn the very first stitch, called the running stitch!

slides.text: Show how to hold the needle: 'Hold it like a pencil. Push it UP through the fabric from the back. Pull the thread all the way through until the knot stops it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's learn how to hold our needle. Hold it just like you hold a crayon or a pencil. We're going to poke it up through the felt, and then pull the thread until it stops.

slides.text: 'Now push the needle DOWN through the fabric a little way ahead. Then UP again. Down, up, down, up — like a dolphin jumping in and out of the water!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we push the needle back down into the felt just a little bit away from where we came up. Then, we poke it up again, and down, and up! It looks like a little zigzag, like a happy dolphin jumping!

slides.text: 'Try to make your stitches even — all about the same size. Not too big, not too tiny. Take your time. Sewing is slow, careful work.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we sew, we want our stitches to be friends and stay close together, all about the same size. It's okay to go slow and be careful, that's how we make our sewing look super neat.

slides.prompt: Sew a line of running stitches across your felt square. Try to keep them even. If you finish one line, try another line below it in a different color thread!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try! Let's make a line of stitches across our felt, going up and down, up and down. Try to make them nice and even, and if you want, you can even try another line with a different color thread!

slides.text: 'You are sewing! This stitch is the building block of all sewing. We will use it to make something special this week — a felt pouch you can keep things in!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sew a line of at least 8 running stitches with reasonable evenness?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You made stitches and learned how to sew! This is how we make all sorts of things, and soon we'll use this stitch to make a special little pouch for your treasures!

parent_notes: Sewing is one of the most valuable practical life activities for the older primary child. It develops fine motor precision, bilateral coordination (one hand holds the fabric, the other guides the needle), patience, and sustained concentration. Felt is the ideal starter fabric because it does not fray, holds its shape, and is thick enough for a blunt needle to pass through without slipping. Drawing a dotted line on the felt gives the child a guide to follow. If the child struggles with threading the needle, you can pre-thread it. The running stitch is used in real sewing — the child is learning a genuine life skill, not a simplified version.

title: Silent Letters — KN and WR Words
description: The child discovers that some English words have SILENT letters — letters that are written but not spoken. This lesson introduces 'kn' (the k is silent, as in knee) and 'wr' (the w is silent, as in write).
instructions:
1. Write 'knee' on the board. 'Read this word. It starts with the /n/ sound. But what letters do you see at the beginning?'
2. 'The k is SILENT! We write it but don't say it. When you see kn at the beginning of a word, only say the /n/.'
3. Build KN words: knee, knot, know, knife, knock, knight, knit, knob.
4. 'Now look at this word: write. What sound does it start with? /r/! But there is a silent W at the beginning!'
5. Build WR words: write, wrong, wrap, wrist, wreck, wren, wreath.
6. Sort: KN words and WR words.
7. Read: 'The knight knew how to write with his right hand. He knocked on the wrong door and wrecked the wreath!'
materials_needed: Reading passage with silent letter words

slides.heading: Silent Letters
slides.subheading: KN and WR — Letters You See But Don't Hear
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we're going to learn about a super fun secret in our words: silent letters! These are letters that we write down, but we don't actually say them out loud when we talk. It's like they're playing hide-and-seek with their sounds!

items: Word cards for KN and WR
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word cards. Label sorting mat KN and WR. Write the reading passage in large, clear print.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool things we get to use for our word games today! We have special letter pieces, a board to write on, cards with words on them, and a mat to put them on. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things so we can play together!

slides.text: 'English has a funny secret: some letters are SILENT! They are in the word but you don't say them. Watch...' Write KNEE. 'What sound does this start with?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to write a word together: KNEE. See how it starts? We're going to think about the sound it makes when we say it. What sound do you hear at the very beginning?

slides.text: 'It starts with /n/ — but there is a K before the N! The K is SILENT. When you see KN together, the K is quiet. You only hear the N.'
slides.mascot_explanation: That's right, it sounds like it starts with the /n/ sound, like in "nose"! But look closely, there's a letter 'K' right before the 'N'. That 'K' is being super quiet; it's a silent letter, so we don't say it at all!

slides.text: Build KN words: knee, knot, know, knife, knock, knight, knit, knob. 'The K is hiding in all of these words — written but not spoken!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build some more words where the 'K' is silent, like "knot" and "knife"! Remember, when you see 'KN' at the start, you just say the /n/ sound. It's like the 'K' is taking a little nap!

slides.text: 'Here is another silent letter: WRITE. It starts with /r/, but there is a silent W! When you see WR, the W is quiet.' Build: write, wrong, wrap, wrist, wreck, wren.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's another word: WRITE! Does it sound like it starts with a 'W'? Nope! It sounds like it starts with the /r/ sound, just like "rabbit." That 'W' is silent, hiding in there, so we only hear the 'R' sound.

slides.prompt: Sort all the word cards into KN and WR columns. Then read: 'The knight knew how to write. He knocked on the wrong door and wrecked the wreath!' Circle every silent letter.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play a sorting game! We'll take all the word cards and put the 'KN' words in one pile and the 'WR' words in another. Then, we'll read a fun sentence and find all the silent letters, just like a word detective!

slides.text: 'English has silent letters because words have HISTORIES — hundreds of years ago, people DID say the K in knee and the W in write! The sounds changed but the spelling stayed. You are learning the secrets of English!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 5 kn words and 5 wr words, identifying the silent letter in each?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about silent letters today! You discovered that sometimes letters are written but not heard, like the 'K' in 'knee' and the 'W' in 'write.' It’s like you learned a secret code for reading!

parent_notes: Silent letters are fascinating because they reveal the history of English. In Old English, the k in 'knee' and the w in 'write' WERE pronounced! Over centuries, the sounds dropped away but the spelling preserved the original pronunciation. Sharing this history with children transforms silent letters from arbitrary annoyances into detective clues about language evolution. Children find it exciting to know they are reading words that have been spelled the same way for hundreds of years. The Montessori approach to phonics systematically builds from regular patterns (CVC) through exceptions (silent letters), giving children a complete toolkit for reading English.

title: Money — Counting Coins and Simple Purchases
description: The child practices counting mixed groups of pennies, nickels, and dimes, then uses coins to make purchases in a play store. This consolidates coin identification, counting, and making exact change.
instructions:
1. Quick review: penny = 1 cent, nickel = 5 cents, dime = 10 cents.
2. Counting challenge: Give the child random groups of coins to count. Start with dimes first!
3. 'How many different ways can you make 25 cents?' Explore: 2 dimes + 1 nickel, 5 nickels, 1 dime + 3 nickels, etc.
4. Introduction to QUARTER: 'There is a special coin worth 25 cents — a QUARTER!' Show it.
5. Play store with prices up to 50 cents.
6. 'Can you make EXACT change for each item? What is the fewest coins you can use?'
7. Begin change-making: 'You paid 30 cents for a 22 cent item. How much change?'
materials_needed: Real US coins: pennies (20), nickels (10), dimes (10), quarters (4)
Items with price labels (up to 50 cents)

slides.heading: Money
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is our special lesson about money! We are going to learn how to count different kinds of coins and use them to buy fun things, just like in a real store!

items: Real coins: pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a store with 5-6 items priced between 10-50 cents. Give the child a wallet or cup with assorted coins. Include quarters for the new introduction.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these treasures we need for our money adventure! We have shiny coins like pennies, nickels, and dimes, and a new friend called a quarter! We also have some fun toys with prices on them, and a special tray to keep our money safe. Ask a grown-up to help you gather these so we can start playing store!

slides.text: 'You are getting great at counting coins! Today we meet one more coin: the QUARTER. It is worth 25 cents — the same as 25 pennies or 5 nickels!' Show the quarter.
slides.mascot_explanation: You are already so good at counting coins! Today, we get to meet a very special coin called a quarter. It's like a super coin because it's worth the same as 25 pennies or 5 nickels all put together!

slides.text: 'The quarter has George Washington on the front. Each state has its own design on the back! 25 cents is a very useful amount.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This coin is special because it has a picture of a very important person, George Washington, on it! It's worth 25 cents, and knowing that helps us with our shopping.

slides.text: 'Challenge: how many ways can you make 25 cents? Try it! 2 dimes + 1 nickel. 5 nickels. 25 pennies. 1 dime + 3 nickels. What else?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a fun puzzle! Can you figure out different ways to make 25 cents using our coins? Maybe two dimes and a nickel? Or five nickels? Let's see how many ways we can make this special amount!

slides.text: 'Now let's shop! Look at each price. Count out the exact amount. Try to use the FEWEST coins possible — that is the most efficient way!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to go shopping! We need to look at the price tag for each toy we want. Then, we'll count out the *exact* amount of money using our coins. Try to use the fewest coins you can, like using a quarter instead of lots of pennies!

slides.prompt: Buy 3 items from the store using exact change. Record each purchase: item, price, coins used. Then challenge: find 3 different ways to make 30 cents.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be a super shopper! Let's pick three toys and pay for them with the exact change. After that, we'll have another fun challenge: can you find three different ways to make 30 cents using our coins?

slides.text: 'You know FOUR coins now: penny, nickel, dime, and quarter! You can count coins, make exact change, and find multiple ways to make the same amount. You are a money mathematician!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count mixed coins including quarters, make purchases up to 50 cents with exact change, and find at least 2 ways to make 25 cents?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You are now a money expert! You know four kinds of coins: the penny, the nickel, the dime, and the amazing quarter! You can count them, use them to buy things, and even find different ways to make amounts. You did such a great job today!

parent_notes: Introducing the quarter completes the standard set of US coins for young children. The quarter is especially useful because many real-world items are priced in quarter increments (gumball machines, parking meters, laundry machines). The challenge of finding multiple ways to make the same amount develops flexible mathematical thinking — there is not one right answer, but many solutions. This mirrors the Montessori emphasis on creative problem-solving. In daily life, give your child opportunities to handle real money: paying for small items, counting change, depositing coins in a savings jar. Real experience accelerates understanding far beyond any exercise.

title: Biomes of the World — Review and Mapping
description: The child reviews all four biomes studied (forest, desert, ocean, grassland) and maps them onto a world map, creating a colorful biome map that shows where each habitat exists on Earth. This synthesizes weeks of science and geography learning.
instructions:
1. Review all four biomes: forest, desert, ocean, grassland. 'We have studied each one. Now let's see where they all are on the WHOLE world!'
2. Provide a blank world map outline.
3. Create a color key: green = forest, yellow = desert, blue = ocean, brown/tan = grassland.
4. 'Let's color the map! Where are the big forests?' Guide: Amazon, Congo, boreal forests across Canada and Russia.
5. 'Where are the deserts?' Sahara, Arabian, Australian, Gobi.
6. 'Grasslands?' African savanna, North American prairie, Asian steppe, South American pampas.
7. 'The ocean is everywhere else!' Color remaining areas blue.
materials_needed: Colored pencils or crayons (green, yellow, blue, brown)

slides.heading: Biomes of the World
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Biomes of the World." That means we're going to learn all about the special homes where animals and plants live all around our big planet Earth.

items: Colored pencils: green, yellow, blue, brown
slides.setup_instructions: Print a blank world map outline. Prepare a color key card. Have the globe available for reference. This is a synthesis activity.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our special project! We have a big paper with a picture of the world, and colorful crayons. We also need a map of the world or a globe, and some pictures of different places. Ask your grown-up to help you gather them all!

slides.text: 'We have explored four amazing biomes: forest, desert, ocean, and grassland. Today we put them ALL on one map — a BIOME MAP of the whole world!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We've learned about so many cool places where animals live, like forests, deserts, oceans, and grassy fields! Today, we get to draw them all on one big map of the whole world so we can see where everything is.

slides.text: 'First, our color key: GREEN for forests, YELLOW for deserts, BLUE for oceans, and BROWN for grasslands. Write the key on the bottom of your map.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our secret code for coloring! We're going to color the big forests GREEN, the dry, sandy deserts YELLOW, the big blue oceans BLUE, and the grassy fields BROWN. We'll write this code on our map so we don't forget!

slides.text: 'Start with oceans — they are the easiest! Color all the water blue. That is most of the map! Now find the forests: the Amazon in South America, the Congo in Africa, and the big northern forests across Canada and Russia.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's start with the water! Can you see all the blue parts on the map? That's the big ocean, and we color it blue! Then, we look for the green forests, like the really big ones in South America and Africa, and color those green.

slides.text: 'Deserts in yellow: the huge Sahara in Africa, deserts in Australia, the Arabian desert, the Gobi in Asia. Grasslands in brown: savannas in Africa, prairies in North America, pampas in South America.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's find the yellow deserts where it's super hot and dry, like in Africa and Australia, and color those yellow. Then we'll color the brown grasslands, like where the lions roar in Africa, brown!

slides.prompt: Complete your biome map! Color all four biomes. Then look at your finished map and answer: which biome covers the most area? Which continent has the most different biomes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to finish our amazing map! We color all the different places: the blue oceans, the green forests, the yellow deserts, and the brown grasslands. After we're done, we can see which color covers the most space on our whole Earth!

slides.text: 'Your biome map shows how Earth's habitats are arranged! Oceans cover the most area. Every continent has multiple biomes. The world is incredibly diverse, and you now understand WHY different animals and people live the way they do.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly color at least 2 examples of each biome on the world map and explain the color key?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Your map shows all the amazing homes for animals around the world. We learned that the big blue ocean covers the most space, and that our Earth has so many different kinds of places. You're a super map maker!

parent_notes: This synthesis activity is a cornerstone of Montessori cosmic education — helping the child see the big picture of how Earth's systems are organized. By coloring a biome map, the child physically engages with global geography while reinforcing the science concepts learned over the past weeks. The finished map is a visual achievement that integrates weeks of learning into a single, beautiful product. Display it prominently. You might notice that the biome boundaries are imprecise — that is fine. The goal is broad understanding, not cartographic precision. The child is developing a framework for understanding Earth's ecological diversity that will deepen throughout their education.

title: Read-Aloud: Koala Lou by Mem Fox
description: Reading 'Koala Lou,' a tender Australian story about a young koala who enters the Bush Olympics to hear her mother say 'I DO love you!' This story explores the universal need for parental love and the fear that love might be conditional.
instructions:
1. 'This story comes from AUSTRALIA — remember, we just learned about Oceania! It is about a little koala.'
2. Show the cover. Read about Koala Lou, who was the first in her family and adored by her mother.
3. As siblings arrive, Koala Lou fears her mother no longer notices her.
4. She enters the Bush Olympics to win and hear her mother's love. She trains for the gum tree climbing event.
5. She comes in SECOND — not first. She is devastated.
6. Her mother runs to her: 'Koala Lou, I DO love you!' The love was always there.
7. Discuss: 'Was her mother's love ever gone? Did she have to WIN to be loved?'
materials_needed: Koala Lou by Mem Fox (illustrated by Pamela Lofts)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to read a special story called "Koala Lou." It's going to be so much fun to read together!

slides.setup_instructions: Show Australia on the globe before reading. Koalas live only in Australia — this connects to our Oceania study.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at these things we need for our story time! We have the book "Koala Lou," a super cozy spot to snuggle up, and this big round ball called a globe. We'll find Australia on the globe because that's where Koala Lou lives!

slides.text: 'This story is from Australia — where we just learned about on our puzzle map! It is about a koala named Koala Lou. Koalas live only in Australia, in eucalyptus trees.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This story comes all the way from a place called Australia! Remember when we learned about Australia on our map? It's where the cute, sleepy koalas live way up in the trees.

slides.text: Read about Koala Lou being adored: 'Koala Lou, I DO love you!' Then more babies arrive and the mother gets busy. Koala Lou misses hearing those words.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read about Koala Lou and how much her mama loved her. But then, some new brothers and sisters came, and Koala Lou started to feel a little bit sad because she missed hearing those special words.

slides.text: She decides to WIN the Bush Olympics gum tree climbing event. She trains hard. 'She wanted to hear those words again more than anything in the world.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no! Koala Lou is going to try her very best to win a big race called the Bush Olympics. She's practicing super hard because she really, really wants to hear her mama say "I love you!"

slides.prompt: Koala Lou came in second and was so sad. But her mother hugged her and said 'I DO love you!' Did her mother ever stop loving her? Do you have to win to be loved?
slides.mascot_explanation: Koala Lou didn't win first place, and she felt so sad. But guess what? Her mama still gave her a big hug and told her she loved her! Do you think her mama ever stopped loving her, even when she didn't win?

slides.text: 'A parent's love is not something you have to earn or win. It is always there, even when they are busy. Koala Lou's mother loved her every single moment — she just forgot to say it out loud.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that Koala Lou's mother always loved her and that love does not depend on winning or achievement?
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't that nice? A mommy's love is always there, just like a big warm hug, even if they're busy. Koala Lou's mama loved her all the time, she just needed to remember to say it!

parent_notes: Koala Lou addresses one of childhood's deepest fears: that a parent's love might be conditional or might fade when siblings arrive. This is a profoundly important book for any child, and particularly relevant for children who are becoming 'older siblings.' Mem Fox's writing is lyrical and perfect for reading aloud. The climax — Koala Lou coming in second and being devastated, then her mother's unconditional embrace — is deeply moving. After reading, explicitly tell your child what Koala Lou's mother eventually realized: say 'I love you' out loud, often. Connect to the Montessori philosophy: we value each child for who they are, not for what they achieve.

title: Geometric Solids — Matching to Real-World Objects
description: The child revisits the geometric solids and matches each one to real-world objects found in the home. This extension activity moves from concrete material to abstract recognition, deepening geometric understanding.
instructions:
1. Review all geometric solids: sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid, rectangular prism, triangular prism, ovoid, ellipsoid.
2. 'These shapes are EVERYWHERE in the real world! Let's go on a shape hunt.'
3. Give the child a bag or basket. 'Find one object for each solid shape.'
4. Match objects to solids: ball = sphere, box = rectangular prism, can = cylinder, funnel = cone, etc.
5. Discuss each match: 'Why is a can a cylinder? It has two flat circles and a curved side.'
6. The child draws each solid and its matching real-world object.
7. 'Architects, engineers, and artists all use these shapes every day!'
materials_needed: Basket or bag for collecting objects

slides.heading: Geometric Solids
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We are going to play a fun game today called a "Shape Hunt," where we find shapes all around us, just like a detective! We’ll look for real things that look like special shapes.

slides.setup_instructions: Set all geometric solids on the work mat. Clear a space next to each one where the child can place their matching real-world object.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, friend, let’s get our special tools ready for our shape adventure! See these cool blocks? They are our shape friends – a ball shape, a box shape, and a can shape. We also have a basket to collect our treasures and paper and a pencil to draw them!

slides.text: 'You know all these 3D shapes by name. Today we discover them hiding in everyday objects! Every building, every toy, every container has a geometric solid shape.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know all these super cool shapes already, like a ball and a box! Today, we're going to pretend to be shape detectives and find these shapes hiding in things all around our house. Everything we see is made of these shapes!

slides.text: 'Let's start: what objects in this room look like a SPHERE? (Ball, orange, globe.) A CUBE? (Dice, block, some boxes.) A CYLINDER? (Can, cup, marker.)'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's start looking around our room right now! Can you see anything that looks like a round ball, a perfect cube like a block, or a tall can shape? Look high and low, we're going to find them!

slides.text: 'Now go on a SHAPE HUNT! Take your basket and find one real object for each geometric solid. Bring them back and match them.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for our big shape hunt! Grab your basket, and let's tiptoe around the house to find one real thing that looks like each of our shape friends. When we find something, we’ll bring it back to match it up!

slides.text: Review each match: 'Why is this can a cylinder? Show me the flat circles at the top and bottom. Show me the curved surface around the side. Perfect match!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job finding that can! Let’s look closely. See how it has flat circles on the top and bottom, and a curved side all around? That’s exactly why it’s a cylinder shape, just like our cylinder block!

slides.prompt: Find at least 6 real objects that match different geometric solids. Place each next to its matching solid. Then draw each pair: the solid and its real-world match. Label everything!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let’s put on our artist hats! We need to draw each shape and the real thing we found that looks like it. You did such a good job finding all these shapes, now we get to draw them to remember them!

slides.text: 'Geometric shapes are the building blocks of EVERYTHING in the world. Buildings, furniture, food, nature — once you can see the shapes, you see them everywhere. You have geometric eyes now!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find and correctly match at least 6 real-world objects to their corresponding geometric solids?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a super shape detective! You found so many things that look just like our special shapes, like the ball and the box. Now you have "geometric eyes" and can see shapes everywhere you look!

parent_notes: This extension activity is powerfully Montessori because it transfers learning from the prepared material to the real world — the ultimate goal of all Montessori education. When the child can see a cylinder in a soup can and a sphere in an orange, they are demonstrating genuine geometric understanding. This awareness does not fade; it becomes a permanent lens through which the child views the world. The shape hunt is joyful and can become a family game: spot geometric solids while driving, shopping, or walking. Architecture is particularly rich with shapes — point out domes (hemispheres), columns (cylinders), and pyramids when you encounter them.

title: Silent Letters — GN and MB Words
description: Continuing silent letter exploration with 'gn' (the g is silent, as in gnat) and 'mb' (the b is silent, as in lamb). The child now knows four silent letter patterns and practices reading words with these tricky spellings.
instructions:
1. Review kn and wr from Day 1.
2. Introduce 'gn': Write 'gnat' on the board. 'A tiny biting insect. It starts with /n/ but has a silent G before the N!'
3. Build GN words: gnat, gnaw, gnome, sign, design, align.
4. Introduce 'mb': Write 'lamb' on the board. 'A baby sheep. It ends with /m/ but has a silent B after the M!'
5. Build MB words: lamb, climb, comb, thumb, bomb, crumb, limb, numb.
6. Sort all four silent letter patterns: KN, WR, GN, MB.
7. Read: 'The gnome climbed the limb to comb his hair. He knew the sign said Do Not Knock!'
materials_needed: Word cards for all four silent letter patterns
Four-column sorting mat (KN, WR, GN, MB)

slides.heading: Silent Letters
slides.subheading: GN and MB — More Hidden Letters
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to learn about super sneaky letters today! Sometimes letters hide in words, and we don't say them out loud. We'll find out which ones are playing hide-and-seek in words with GN and MB.

items: Word cards for KN, WR, GN, MB
slides.setup_instructions: Label sorting mat with all four patterns. Prepare word cards for all four groups. Have the reading passage ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need for our game! We have letters we can move around, a special board to write on, and cards with words on them. We'll use these to put the words in the right spots, just like a puzzle!

slides.text: 'We found silent K in kn and silent W in wr. Today we meet TWO MORE silent letters! First: GNAT. A gnat is a tiny insect. What sound starts this word? /n/! The G is SILENT.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We already learned about some silent letters, like the K in 'kn' and the W in 'wr'. Today we have two new ones! See the word 'gnat'? It sounds like 'nat', because the 'g' is quiet! That's a new trick for our ears.

slides.text: Build GN words: gnat, gnaw, gnome. 'GN at the beginning — the G is always quiet.' Also: sign, design, align. 'GN at the end — still silent!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's play with words that start with GN, like 'gnome' and 'gnaw', where the G is quiet. We'll also find words that end with GN, like 'sign', and the G is still hiding! It's like a secret code.

slides.text: 'Last one: LAMB. A baby sheep. Say it: /lam/. The B at the end is SILENT!' Build MB words: lamb, climb, comb, thumb, crumb, numb, limb, bomb.
slides.mascot_explanation: And look, here's 'lamb'! It sounds like 'lam', because the 'b' at the end is silent. We'll make words like 'climb', 'comb', and 'thumb' where the 'b' is taking a nap.

slides.text: 'Now sort ALL four silent letter patterns! You are a silent letter expert: KN (silent k), WR (silent w), GN (silent g), MB (silent b).'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be word detectives! We're going to take all our word cards and put them in the right piles. We'll sort words with silent K, silent W, silent G, and silent B. You can do it!

slides.prompt: Sort all word cards into four columns. Then read: 'The gnome knew he should climb the limb. He combed his thumb and knocked on the wrong sign.' Circle every silent letter in the passage!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's read a story together and find all the silent letters! We'll read about a gnome and his adventures, and then we'll circle the letters that are hiding. It's like a treasure hunt for sounds!

slides.text: 'You know FOUR silent letter patterns: kn, wr, gn, and mb! These are English spelling secrets. When you see these patterns, you know to skip the silent letter. You are reading like a detective!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the silent letter in words from all four patterns and read mixed silent-letter sentences fluently?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are a super silent letter expert now. You found the hidden letters in KN, WR, GN, and MB words! That means you can read even trickier words, just like a real reading detective.

parent_notes: Completing the silent letter series gives the child a systematic toolkit for some of English's trickiest spellings. These patterns appear in common, everyday words (know, write, sign, climb) so the child will encounter them frequently. The historical context is fascinating: the b in 'lamb' was pronounced in Old English as /lamb-b/, and the g in 'gnat' was pronounced as a hard /g/. These sounds softened over centuries. Children who understand that spellings have historical reasons are less frustrated by irregularities and more curious about language. The sorting activity across all four patterns develops the child's ability to categorize and distinguish, which is a fundamental cognitive skill.

title: Clock Introduction — Reading Hours
description: Introduction to telling time using an analog clock. The child learns the parts of a clock (face, numbers, hour hand, minute hand) and how to read the hour when the minute hand points to 12.
instructions:
1. Present a teaching clock with moveable hands.
2. 'A clock tells us WHAT TIME it is. Let's learn its parts.'
3. Identify: the face (circle), the numbers (1-12), the short hand (HOUR hand), the long hand (MINUTE hand).
4. 'The SHORT hand tells the HOUR. When the long hand points straight up to 12, we read the hour.'
5. Set the clock to 3:00. 'The short hand is on 3. The long hand is on 12. It is 3 o'clock!'
6. Practice reading: 1:00, 5:00, 8:00, 12:00, 6:00.
7. 'What time do you eat breakfast? What time do you go to bed? Let's show those times on the clock!'
materials_needed: Real analog clock or watch for comparison

slides.heading: Telling Time
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We are going to learn all about telling time. This is like a special game where we find out what time it is.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the teaching clock where the child can easily move the hands. Have a real clock nearby for comparison. Start with both hands at 12 (12:00).
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need! We have a special clock with hands we can move, and maybe some paper and a pencil to draw. We might even look at a real clock at home to see what it looks like! Ask a grown-up to help you find these so we can play.

slides.text: 'A clock is a tool that tells us what time it is. Look at this clock — it has a round FACE with numbers 1 through 12. And TWO HANDS that point to the numbers.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This big circle is called a clock face, and it has numbers all around it, just like counting! It also has two pointy hands that move around to show us the time. We're going to learn what those hands mean.

slides.text: 'The SHORT hand is the HOUR hand — it tells which hour of the day it is. The LONG hand is the MINUTE hand — it tells the minutes. For now, we will focus on the HOUR hand.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See the two hands? One is short and one is long. The short hand is the super important one for telling us the hour, like what number we are on right now. The long hand helps too, but we'll focus on the short one for now!

slides.text: Set to 3:00: 'When the long hand points to 12, we look at the short hand. It points to 3. It is 3 O'CLOCK!' Move to 7:00: 'Short hand on 7, long hand on 12 — 7 o'clock!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, when the long hand is pointing all the way up to the 12, and the short hand is pointing to the 3, it means it's 3 o'clock! It's like saying "three times around the clock!" Now, if the short hand is on the 7 and the long hand is on the 12, it's 7 o'clock!

slides.text: 'Your turn! I will say a time and YOU set the clock: show me 5 o'clock. Show me 9 o'clock. Show me 1 o'clock.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's your turn to be the clock master! Can you move the hands to show me 5 o'clock? Great job! Now, can you show me 9 o'clock? You're doing so good!

slides.prompt: Set the clock to show these times: 8:00 (breakfast), 12:00 (lunch), 3:00 (snack), 7:00 (dinner), 8:00 (bedtime). Draw each clock face and write the time below it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to show what time we do important things! Let's move the clock hands to show when we eat breakfast, and then when we eat dinner. Can you also show me what time you go to bed? You can even draw what each time looks like!

slides.text: 'You can read the hour on a clock! The short hand shows the hour, and when the long hand is on 12, you know it is exactly that hour. Next time, we will learn about the HALF HOUR!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and set the clock correctly for any hour (o'clock) position?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You learned how to read the hour on a clock! You know that the short hand tells us the hour, and when the long hand is on the 12, it's exactly that time. High five, super clock reader!

parent_notes: Telling time is a life skill that connects math to daily routine. The analog clock is important even in the digital age because it provides a VISUAL representation of time passing — you can SEE that 3:00 is halfway through the afternoon. Start with only the hour (o'clock times) to build confidence before introducing half-hours and minutes. The teaching clock allows the child to manipulate the hands, making time tangible. Connect to the child's daily routine: 'You wake up at 7 o'clock, start lessons at 9 o'clock, eat lunch at 12 o'clock.' This grounds the abstract concept of time in lived experience. Point out clocks in the home and discuss what the hands show.

title: Animal Classification Review — Vertebrates and Invertebrates
description: The child reviews animal classification with a focus on vertebrates (animals with backbones) and invertebrates (animals without). They sort animals from all four biomes into these categories, building a comprehensive understanding of the animal kingdom.
instructions:
1. 'We have studied many animals in our biome lessons. Now let's organize them! All animals belong to one of two big groups.'
2. Feel your backbone: 'Put your hand on the back of your neck. Feel those bumps? That is your BACKBONE — your spine!'
3. 'Animals WITH backbones are called VERTEBRATES. Animals WITHOUT backbones are called INVERTEBRATES.'
4. Show examples: vertebrates (fish, frogs, snakes, birds, mammals). Invertebrates (insects, spiders, worms, jellyfish, octopus).
5. Sort animals from all biome studies: 'Is a dolphin a vertebrate or invertebrate? A spider? A lion?'
6. 'Most of the animals on Earth are invertebrates — especially insects!'
7. Draw one vertebrate and one invertebrate. Label the backbone.
materials_needed: Animal cards from biome studies (at least 15-20)

slides.heading: Animal Classification
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this slide! It has a big title that says "Animal Classification" and tells us we're going to learn about two special groups of animals: "Vertebrates" and "Invertebrates." We're going to become animal experts today!

items: Animal cards from all biome studies
slides.setup_instructions: Collect animal cards from all previous biome lessons. Label sorting mat Vertebrate and Invertebrate. Have the backbone diagram visible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are all the fun things we need for our animal sorting game! We have our animal pictures from all our trips to the forest, the ocean, and everywhere else. We also have a special mat to help us sort them, a picture that shows what a backbone looks like, and paper and crayons for drawing. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'We have met SO many animals — from forests, deserts, oceans, and grasslands. Now let's organize them into two BIG groups. Feel the back of your neck — those bumps are your BACKBONE!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first step is like a little detective mission! We're going to take all those animal friends we've met and put them into two big, important groups. First, let's feel our own bodies – put your hand on the back of your neck and feel those little bumps. That’s your backbone, and it helps you stand up tall!

slides.text: 'Animals WITH a backbone are called VERTEBRATES — that includes you! Fish, frogs, snakes, birds, and mammals ALL have backbones. We are vertebrates!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's learn about the first group! Animals that have a backbone, just like you and me, are called vertebrates. So, if you feel your backbone, you are a vertebrate, and so are fish, birds, and even big lions!

slides.text: 'Animals WITHOUT a backbone are called INVERTEBRATES. Insects, spiders, worms, jellyfish, and octopuses have NO bones at all! They are squishy or have a hard outside shell instead.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the other big group! Animals that do NOT have a backbone are called invertebrates. Think of wiggly worms or tiny ants – they don’t have bones inside them, and that’s okay!

slides.text: 'Here is the surprising part: MOST animals on Earth are invertebrates! There are more insects than all vertebrates combined. Invertebrates rule the animal kingdom!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't this interesting? Most of the animals in the whole world don't have backbones, they are invertebrates! There are so, so many tiny bugs and other creatures that are invertebrates. They are super important too!

slides.prompt: Sort all the animal cards into two groups: Vertebrate and Invertebrate. Then draw one of each and label the backbone on the vertebrate (or write 'no backbone' for the invertebrate).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time for our super fun activity! Let's take all those animal pictures we have and sort them onto our mat into the "Vertebrate" pile and the "Invertebrate" pile. After we sort them, let's pick one of each to draw, and we can draw a backbone on the vertebrate one. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Every animal is either a vertebrate (backbone) or an invertebrate (no backbone). YOU are a vertebrate! You share that feature with fish, birds, lions, and whales. Scientists use classification to organize the millions of species on Earth.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define vertebrate and invertebrate, and correctly sort at least 10 animals into the two categories?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job sorting all the animals! Remember, animals with backbones are vertebrates, like you and me, and animals without are invertebrates. We learned that even though most animals are invertebrates, they are all special in their own way. You are a super scientist!

parent_notes: Classification is a fundamental scientific skill and a key part of Montessori zoology. The vertebrate/invertebrate distinction is the first major division in the animal kingdom and gives children a framework for organizing the vast diversity of animal life. The physical experience of feeling their own backbone makes the concept personal and concrete. Many children are surprised to learn that invertebrates vastly outnumber vertebrates — insects alone represent over 80% of all animal species. This challenges the common assumption that 'big' animals are the norm. Sorting the animals from all four biome studies reviews content while introducing a new organizing principle, which is a higher-order thinking skill.

title: Art — Self-Portrait Drawing
description: The child creates a detailed self-portrait by observing themselves in a mirror. This develops observational skills, body awareness, and proportional understanding while building self-identity and self-expression.
instructions:
1. 'Today you are both the artist AND the model! You will draw a picture of YOUR face by looking in a mirror.'
2. Set up a mirror at the child's eye level. Provide paper and drawing supplies.
3. 'Look carefully at your face. What SHAPE is it? Oval? Round? Heart-shaped?'
4. Guide observation: 'Where are your eyes? In the middle of your face! Not at the top. Your nose is between your eyes and chin. Your mouth is below your nose.'
5. 'What color are your eyes? Your hair? What makes YOUR face special?'
6. The child draws, looking back and forth between the mirror and paper.
7. Add color. Sign the portrait.

slides.heading: Art
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is our special art time, and today we get to make a picture of YOU! It's called a self-portrait, and it's going to be super fun.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a mirror where the child can see their face clearly while drawing. Good lighting is important. Position the paper right next to the mirror.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our amazing picture, we need a few things! We need a mirror so you can see your own smiley face, some paper to draw on, and pencils and crayons to make it colorful. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these special art tools?

slides.text: 'Artists throughout history have drawn SELF-PORTRAITS — pictures of their own face. Frida Kahlo, Vincent van Gogh, and Rembrandt all painted themselves! Today you will draw YOU.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Did you know that artists a long, long time ago made pictures of themselves too? Today, YOU get to be the artist *and* the person in the picture! We're going to draw a picture of your own wonderful face.

slides.text: 'Look in the mirror. What shape is your face? Draw that shape lightly with pencil. Now look at where your eyes are — they are in the MIDDLE of your face, not at the top!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look in the mirror very carefully. What shape is your face? Is it round like a ball or more like an oval? Let's draw that shape very lightly first. And look, your eyes are right in the middle, not way up high!

slides.text: 'Draw your eyes. What shape are they? What color? Now your nose — it sits between your eyes and your chin. Your mouth — what expression are you making?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, let's draw your eyes. What color are they? And your nose is sitting right between your eyes and your chin. What about your mouth? Are you making a big smile or a little one?

slides.text: 'Add your hair — what color, what texture? Is it straight, curly, wavy? What about eyebrows and ears? Now add color to bring your portrait to life.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to draw your hair! Is it long or short? Is it curly or straight? We can also add your eyebrows and ears. Then, we'll use our colorful crayons or pencils to make your picture really pop!

slides.prompt: Complete your self-portrait. Look back and forth between the mirror and your paper. Add details: freckles, dimples, glasses, a smile. When finished, sign it in the corner like a real artist!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to finish our masterpiece! Look back and forth between the mirror and your drawing. Let's add all the special things that make your face YOU, like maybe some freckles or a cute dimple. When you're all done, we'll sign our name like a real artist!

slides.text: 'You have created a self-portrait — a piece of art that shows the world who YOU are! Every person's face is unique and beautiful. Artists celebrate that uniqueness in their portraits.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a recognizable self-portrait with facial features in approximately correct proportions?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at your amazing self-portrait! You drew a picture of yourself, and it shows everyone how special and unique you are. Every face is beautiful, and you made a wonderful piece of art today!

parent_notes: Self-portrait work is valuable both artistically and developmentally. It requires careful observation (a foundational science skill), proportional reasoning (mathematical thinking), and self-awareness (emotional development). The common childhood tendency to place eyes near the top of the head provides a natural teaching moment about proportion — eyes are actually in the middle of the face. Don't correct the child's drawing style; instead, guide their observation: 'Look in the mirror — where are your eyes relative to the top and bottom of your face?' The finished portrait is a wonderful keepsake that captures the child at this moment in time. Consider doing self-portraits periodically to see the child's artistic growth.

title: Sewing — Making a Felt Pouch (Part 1)
description: The child begins making a felt pouch using the running stitch learned earlier. They pin two felt pieces together and sew along three edges, creating a pocket. This is the first part of a two-session project.
instructions:
1. 'Remember the running stitch you practiced? Today we use it to make something real — a FELT POUCH!'
2. Stack two felt rectangles together. 'We will sew THREE sides closed and leave the top OPEN — that is the opening of the pouch!'
3. Pin the three sides with straight pins (adult assists). 'Pins hold the fabric in place while we sew.'
4. Thread the needle and knot the thread.
5. Begin sewing along the bottom edge using running stitch. 'Keep your stitches about the same distance apart.'
6. When you reach a corner, turn and continue up the side.
7. 'We will finish the other side next time. Great start!'

slides.heading: Sewing Project
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make a super cool felt pouch, which is like a little bag you can keep special things in! This is the first time we're making it, so we'll learn how to start our pouch today.

slides.setup_instructions: Cut two matching rectangles from felt. Stack them evenly. Thread the needle with about 24 inches of thread. Have pins ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our project! We have two soft pieces of felt, like a cozy blanket, and a special needle for sewing. We also have some colorful thread to make our stitches, and little pins to hold the felt together. Ask a grown-up to help you find these things so we can get started!

slides.text: 'You practiced the running stitch and you are ready to make something real! We are sewing a POUCH — like a little bag for treasures. Two pieces of felt sewn together on three sides.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we practiced sewing those little stitches? Well, today we get to use that special stitch to make our very own pouch! It's like a tiny bag where you can put your favorite little toys or treasures. We're going to sew up three sides of the felt to make the bag part.

slides.text: 'First, stack the two pieces of felt evenly. Pin along three edges — the bottom and two sides. Leave the TOP open. Pins hold everything in place while you sew.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our felt ready! We need to put the two pieces of felt right on top of each other, nice and neat. Then, we'll use those little pins to hold the bottom and the two sides together, but we leave the top open so we can put things inside our pouch!

slides.text: 'Start sewing along the bottom edge, about half an inch from the edge. Use the running stitch: up, down, up, down. Keep your stitches even and about the same distance apart.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to sew! We're going to start at the bottom edge and use our running stitch, going up and down, up and down, just like we practiced. Try to make your stitches look like little friends lined up, all about the same size.

slides.text: 'When you reach the corner, turn and sew up the side. Remove pins as you go — never sew over a pin!'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we get to the corner, that's where we turn! We'll carefully sew right up the side, making sure to take out the pins before we sew over them. It's important to take them out so our needle doesn't get stuck.

slides.prompt: Sew the bottom edge and at least one side of your pouch. Take your time — even stitches make a stronger pouch! If your thread runs out, tie it off and start a new piece.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you're doing such a great job sewing! Keep going along the edge, making those nice, even stitches. If your thread runs out, don't worry, we can just tie it off and start with a new piece.

slides.text: 'Look at your pouch taking shape! You are creating something useful with your own hands. We will finish sewing and decorate it on Friday!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sew at least two edges of the pouch with consistent running stitches and navigate the corner?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at what you've made! Your pouch is starting to look like a real little bag, and you did that all by yourself! We made one side and the bottom today, and next time we'll finish it up and make it even more special.

parent_notes: This sewing project is a milestone in the child's practical life journey — they are creating a real, functional object. The pouch can hold treasures, coins, or small toys, giving the child's work genuine purpose. Navigating the corner (turning from the bottom edge to the side) requires spatial thinking and problem-solving. If the child's stitches are uneven, that is perfectly fine — the pouch will still work. The imperfections are part of the charm and the learning. Don't redo the child's work. If the thread tangles (which it will), help untangle patiently. Sewing requires managing frustration, which is itself a valuable lesson.

title: Suffixes — Adding -ING to Verbs
description: The child learns that adding the suffix '-ing' to a verb changes it to show an action happening RIGHT NOW. This morphology lesson builds understanding of how word parts change meaning and introduces the concept of suffixes.
instructions:
1. 'We can change words by adding parts to the end! A part added to the end of a word is called a SUFFIX.'
2. Write 'jump' on the board. 'This is a verb — an action word. Now watch: jump + ing = JUMPING! The ing tells us the action is happening NOW.'
3. Practice with simple verbs: walk/walking, talk/talking, read/reading, help/helping, play/playing, sing/singing.
4. 'Are you jumping? No — you jumped. Are you jumping? Yes! I am jumping RIGHT NOW!'
5. Act it out: child walks. 'What are you doing? I am walking!' Run: 'I am running!'
6. Write 5 sentences using -ing words.
7. Note the spelling rule: if a verb ends in 'e,' drop the e before adding -ing: make/making, ride/riding.

slides.heading: Suffixes
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We're going to learn about special word parts that we add to the end of words, like a little surprise! This special part helps us know when something is happening right this very second.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare verb cards (jump, walk, read, play, sing, make, ride). Create -ING cards that can be placed at the end. Have space for movement.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have some exciting things to play with for our word game! We have a whiteboard to write on, cards with action words like "jump" and "walk," and special "-ING" cards. We also need paper and a pencil, so let's ask a grown-up to help us find everything!

slides.text: 'Words are like building blocks — you can ADD parts to change their meaning! A part added to the END of a word is called a SUFFIX. Today we learn the suffix -ING.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how words are like building blocks? Well, we can add little pieces to the end of them to make them say something new! A piece we add at the end is called a suffix, and today we're going to learn a super fun one: "-ING!"

slides.text: Write JUMP: 'This is a verb. Now I add -ING.' Write JUMPING. 'Jumping means you are doing it RIGHT NOW. I am jumping! The -ING makes it present — happening this moment.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this word, "jump"? That's an action word, a verb! Now watch what happens when we add our special "-ING" piece to the end: JUMPING! When we say "jumping," it means you are doing it right now, this very second!

slides.text: Practice: walk + ing = walking, talk + ing = talking, read + ing = reading, play + ing = playing, sing + ing = singing. Place the -ING card after each verb.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play with our word cards! We take a word like "walk" and add our "-ING" card to make "walking," so we know it's happening now. We can do this with "talk" to make "talking," and "read" to make "reading," and "play" to make "playing," and "sing" to make "singing"!

slides.text: 'Let's ACT IT OUT! Walk around the room. What are you doing? I am WALKING!' Run: 'I am RUNNING!' Sit: 'I am SITTING!' The -ing shows what is happening NOW.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend! Can you walk around the room? What are you doing? You are WALKING! Now, can you run super fast? What are you doing? You are RUNNING! And can you sit down? You are SITTING! The "-ING" helps us say what we are doing right now!

slides.prompt: Write 5 sentences using -ing words: 'I am reading a book. The dog is running fast. We are playing outside.' Act out each sentence as you write it!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to write some sentences and act them out! We'll write "I am reading," and then pretend to read a book. Then we'll write "The dog is running," and pretend to run like a doggy! It's like telling a story with our bodies and words!

slides.text: 'The suffix -ing is a powerful word tool! It turns any action word into something happening RIGHT NOW. Tomorrow we will learn more suffixes that change words in different ways.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child add -ing to at least 5 verbs correctly and use them in sentences?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about "-ING" today! It's like a magic spell that tells us something is happening right now. We learned how to add it to lots of words and even act them out! You're becoming a super word helper!

parent_notes: Suffixes are a child's first encounter with morphology — the study of word parts and how they create meaning. The -ing suffix is the most intuitive starting point because children can physically act out the present continuous tense: 'I am jumping!' (while jumping). This kinesthetic connection makes the grammar concept concrete. The spelling rule (drop the silent e before adding -ing: make/making, ride/riding) is introduced lightly here and will be reinforced over time. In Montessori grammar, we use the red action symbol (circle) for verbs — if you have grammar symbols, show that the base verb and the -ing form are both still verbs. Suffixes are gateway skills for more advanced vocabulary development.

title: Clock — Reading Half Hours
description: Building on the hour introduction, the child learns to read the half hour on an analog clock. They discover that when the minute hand points to 6, it means 'half past' — the minute hand has traveled halfway around the clock face.
instructions:
1. Review o'clock times: 'When the long hand is on 12, it is exactly the hour.'
2. 'Now watch what happens...' Move the minute hand from 12 all the way to 6. 'The minute hand went HALFWAY around! It is HALF PAST the hour.'
3. Set to 3:30. 'The short hand is between 3 and 4. The long hand is on 6. It is half past 3, or three-thirty.'
4. Explain: 'Half past means 30 minutes have gone by — half of 60 minutes.'
5. Practice: 1:30, 5:30, 8:30, 10:30, 12:30.
6. Mix o'clock and half-past: 'What time is this?' Show random times.
7. 'What do you do at these times in your day?'

slides.heading: Telling Time
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn all about telling time today, and it's going to be super fun! We'll learn how to read the clock when it's not exactly on the hour, like when it's halfway around.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the teaching clock. Have worksheets with blank clock faces for drawing practice. Connect to the child's daily schedule.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we get to use for our time adventure! We have a special clock to move the hands, and some paper and pencils to draw. We'll also look at our daily schedule to see when things happen, like snack time!

slides.text: 'You can read o'clock times — when the long hand is on 12. Now let's learn what happens when the long hand moves to 6!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about o'clock? That's when the long hand points straight up to the 12. Now, we're going to learn what happens when that long hand takes a little trip!

slides.text: Move the minute hand slowly from 12 to 6: 'The minute hand traveled HALFWAY around the clock. It takes 30 minutes to go halfway. So we say it is HALF PAST the hour.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See how the long hand is moving? It's going all the way around, but not all the way to the top again. It went halfway around to the 6, and that means it's "half past" the hour.

slides.text: Set to 3:30: 'The long hand is on 6 (half past). The short hand is between 3 and 4 — it has moved too! It is half past 3, or 3:30. We can say it both ways.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now look at our clock! The long hand is on the 6, and the short hand is right in the middle between the 3 and the 4. That means it's half past 3, or we can call it 3:30!

slides.text: 'Practice: set the clock to half past 7. Where does the long hand go? (6.) Where is the short hand? (Between 7 and 8.)' Continue with 1:30, 5:30, 10:30.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's practice! Can you help me set the clock to half past 7? The long hand needs to go to the 6, and the short hand will be right between the 7 and the 8. Great job!

slides.prompt: Read these times I set on the clock. Then YOU set the clock to show: 4:30, 9:30, 6:30, 11:30. Draw each clock face on paper and write the time below.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the clock master! I'll show you a time, and you set it, then you can draw it and write the numbers. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You can now tell time to the hour AND the half hour! That covers most of the times in your daily schedule. Keep looking at clocks and practicing — you will get faster every day!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and set both o'clock and half-past times correctly on the teaching clock?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You can now tell time to the hour AND the half hour, which is amazing! Now you can tell what time it is for so many things in your day, like when it's time for lunch!

parent_notes: The half hour is the second step in telling time and introduces a key concept: the hour hand MOVES between numbers as the minutes pass. At 3:30, the hour hand is NOT on the 3 — it is between 3 and 4. This is confusing for many children and needs gentle, repeated demonstration. The language 'half past' connects to math (half of 60 is 30) and to fractions. After this lesson, frequently ask the child to read the time on real clocks in the home. Morning routine, mealtimes, and bedtime are natural check-in points. The analog clock visual helps children develop time sense — an understanding of how long things take and how time is structured — that digital clocks do not provide.

title: Celebrations Around the World — Festivals of Light
description: The child explores how different cultures celebrate with light: Diwali (India), Hanukkah (Jewish), Lantern Festival (China), and Saint Lucia Day (Scandinavia). This cultural study reveals the universal human attraction to light as a symbol of hope and joy.
instructions:
1. 'People all around the world celebrate with LIGHT! Light means hope, happiness, and new beginnings. Let's learn about festivals of light from different cultures.'
2. Diwali: 'In India, families light thousands of small oil lamps called diyas. The whole country glows! Diwali means the triumph of light over darkness.'
3. Hanukkah: 'Jewish families light the menorah — one candle each night for 8 nights, remembering a miracle of oil that lasted 8 days.'
4. Lantern Festival: 'In China, beautiful paper lanterns are released into the sky, celebrating the end of the New Year celebrations.'
5. Saint Lucia Day: 'In Sweden, a girl wears a crown of candles and brings light to the dark winter morning.'
6. 'What do ALL these celebrations have in common? Light! Why do you think light is so important to people?'
7. Child creates their own paper lantern or draws a festival of light scene.
materials_needed: Pictures of Diwali, Hanukkah, Lantern Festival, Saint Lucia Day
Construction paper and scissors (for paper lantern craft)
Battery-operated tea light (optional, for safe demonstration)

slides.heading: Celebrations Around the World
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! We're going to learn about special parties people have all around the world. Some of them use pretty lights!

items: Festival pictures (Diwali, Hanukkah, Lantern Festival, Saint Lucia)
slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures of all four festivals. Show each culture's location on the globe. Have craft materials ready for the lantern project.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some things to help us learn! See these pictures? They show us the special parties. And this big ball is a globe, it shows us where people live! We also have paper and crayons to make something super fun!

slides.text: 'In the dark of winter — or any time people want to celebrate hope — they light candles, lamps, and lanterns. Every culture has a festival of LIGHT!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's dark sometimes, right? Like when you go to sleep? Well, when it's dark, people all over the world like to light up their homes with candles and lamps to feel happy and hopeful.

slides.text: Show India on the globe: 'DIWALI — families light rows of tiny oil lamps called diyas. Streets and homes glow with warm light. Diwali celebrates good winning over evil, light over darkness.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this picture! In a place called India, families light up lots and lots of little lamps. It makes everything so bright and happy, like a happy glow!

slides.text: Show Israel: 'HANUKKAH — Jewish families light the menorah, adding one candle each night for 8 nights. They remember a miracle where one day of oil lasted 8 days.' Show China: 'LANTERN FESTIVAL — glowing paper lanterns fill the sky!'
slides.mascot_explanation: In another place, Jewish families light a special candle holder called a menorah, one candle each night. And in China, they send beautiful glowing lanterns way up high in the sky!

slides.text: Show Sweden: 'SAINT LUCIA DAY — a girl wears a crown of candles and brings rolls and coffee to her family in the dark morning. Light in the darkness!' Ask: 'What do all these have in common?'
slides.mascot_explanation: And in a cold place called Sweden, a girl wears a special crown with lights on it to bring brightness to the morning! See how all these celebrations use light? It helps people feel hopeful.

slides.prompt: Make a paper lantern! Fold construction paper in half, cut slits from the fold, open and roll into a cylinder. Add a handle. Or draw your favorite festival of light scene with bright colors!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to make something bright! We're going to make our very own paper lantern by folding and cutting paper, or you can draw a picture of your favorite light festival. It's going to be so colorful!

slides.text: 'Every culture, everywhere in the world, celebrates with light. Light means hope, warmth, and the promise that darkness will not last forever. We are all connected by our love of light!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 festivals of light, locate the cultures on the globe, and explain the shared theme of light as hope?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job learning about all the light celebrations! You showed me how light makes people feel happy and hopeful, just like in all those special festivals. You're a super star!

parent_notes: Festivals of light are a beautiful topic for cultural studies because they reveal a universal human theme: light as a symbol of hope, renewal, and the triumph of good. This lesson transcends any single religious or cultural tradition by showing children that ALL peoples share this deep connection to light. Present each festival with equal respect and enthusiasm. If your family celebrates one of these festivals, share your personal connection. If not, approach each with genuine curiosity and appreciation. Making a simple paper lantern provides a hands-on connection to the topic. A battery tea light placed inside the paper lantern creates a safe, beautiful demonstration of the concept.

title: Read-Aloud: The Name Jar by Yangsook Choi
description: Reading 'The Name Jar,' a story about a Korean girl named Unhei who starts a new school in America and considers changing her name because classmates cannot pronounce it. This story explores identity, cultural pride, and the beauty of diverse names.
instructions:
1. Show the cover: 'This is about a girl named Unhei (say: OON-hay) who moves from Korea to America.'
2. Read about Unhei's first day — the kids on the bus try to say her name and struggle.
3. She tells her class she hasn't chosen a name yet. Her classmates put name suggestions in a jar.
4. 'Why did Unhei not want to tell her real name? How would you feel?'
5. A boy named Joey learns her Korean name means 'grace.' He puts her real name in the jar.
6. Unhei decides to keep her own name — it was given with love and has beautiful meaning.
7. Discuss: 'Every person's name has a story. What is the story of YOUR name?'
materials_needed: The Name Jar by Yangsook Choi
Optional: jar and paper slips (for name activity)

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Name Jar by Yangsook Choi
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the cover of a special book we're going to read together. It's called "The Name Jar," and it's about a little girl named Unhei.

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably. If doing the name activity, have a jar and paper slips ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story, we need a few things. We need our book, "The Name Jar," and a super cozy spot to sit. If we want to do a fun activity later, we can also get a jar and some little papers ready with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: 'This story is about a girl named Unhei who moves from Korea — remember, Korea is in Asia, on our puzzle map! Her name is beautiful but her new classmates don't know how to say it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our story is about a sweet girl named Unhei who is new to America. In Korea, where she came from, her name sounds just right, but her new friends have a little trouble saying it.

slides.text: Read about the bus ride and the kids struggling with her name. 'How do you think Unhei felt? Embarrassed? Sad? Alone?'
slides.mascot_explanation: On the bus to her new school, the other kids tried to say Unhei's name and it was tricky for them. How do you think that made Unhei feel when they couldn't say her name? Maybe a little shy or sad?

slides.text: When classmates fill the name jar with suggestions: 'They wanted to help, but should Unhei change her name? Her name was chosen by her grandmother and means GRACE in Korean.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When Unhei got to school, her friends put lots of new name ideas into a jar to help her. But Unhei's name was very special; her grandma picked it, and it means "grace," which is a beautiful thing!

slides.prompt: What does YOUR name mean? Who chose it for you? Why? If you don't know, ask your parents! Write your name, its meaning, and who chose it. Every name has a story.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to think about your amazing name! What does your name mean, and who gave it to you? Let's ask a grown-up to help us write it down, because every name has a wonderful story just like Unhei's.

slides.text: 'Unhei kept her beautiful Korean name because it was part of her — given with love, full of meaning. Every person's name deserves to be learned, said correctly, and respected. What a gift our names are!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why Unhei kept her name, and share the story or meaning of their own name?
slides.mascot_explanation: Unhei decided to keep her own name because it was a special gift from her family, and it meant so much to her! It's so important to be proud of our names and help others say them right, because they are a big part of who we are.

parent_notes: The Name Jar addresses identity, cultural pride, and the experience of being different in a deeply empathetic way. For children in homeschool settings, this book builds awareness that not everyone shares their cultural background and that differences in names, languages, and traditions are to be celebrated, not erased. The name activity (researching the meaning and origin of one's own name) personalizes the lesson. If you know the story of how you chose your child's name, share it — children love hearing that their name was chosen with thought and care. This book also connects to the Asia puzzle map and the themes of immigration explored in Grandfather's Journey.

title: Sound Cylinders — Grading and Matching Review
description: The child works with the sound cylinders (two sets), grading them from loudest to softest and matching pairs from opposite sets. This advanced sensorial work refines auditory discrimination and concentration.
instructions:
1. Present the two sets of sound cylinders (red-lidded and blue-lidded).
2. 'Each cylinder has something inside that makes a sound. Your job is to find the MATCHING pairs — the ones that sound the SAME.'
3. Child shakes one red cylinder, then shakes blue cylinders one by one until finding the match.
4. Place matched pairs side by side.
5. Continue until all 6 pairs are matched.
6. 'Now let's GRADE one set! Arrange them from LOUDEST to SOFTEST.'
7. Verify by shaking in sequence: loud... medium... soft.
8. 'Your ears can tell the difference between very similar sounds — that takes great concentration!'

slides.heading: Sound Cylinders
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at the title of our fun game today! It's called "Sound Cylinders," and we're going to play a matching and listening game with them.

items: Sound cylinders (red set and blue set)
slides.setup_instructions: Place the red-lidded set on one side and the blue-lidded set on the other. Work in a quiet room so subtle sound differences can be heard.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special cylinders! We have a red group and a blue group, and they have little tops that make them easy to hold. We'll put them on this soft mat so we can hear them better.

slides.text: 'Today we work with sound! These cylinders each have something inside that makes a noise. The red set and the blue set have MATCHING pairs — cylinders that sound the same.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we get to be super listeners! These special cups have little surprises inside that make different sounds when we shake them. Our job is to find the cups that sound just the same, like twins!

slides.text: 'Pick up one red cylinder and shake it. Listen carefully. Now shake each blue cylinder until you find the one that sounds EXACTLY the same. Matching!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try it! Pick up a red cup and give it a gentle shake, listening very carefully to its sound. Now, shake each blue cup one by one until you find the one that sounds exactly like the red one you just heard.

slides.text: 'Continue until all 6 pairs are matched. Listen closely — some are very similar! Take your time. Your ears need silence and concentration to hear the differences.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Keep listening super hard to find all the matching pairs! Sometimes the sounds are very, very close, so we need to be very quiet and use our best listening ears to find them.

slides.text: 'Now take one complete set and GRADE them — arrange from LOUDEST to SOFTEST. Shake and compare: which is louder? Which is softer? Build the sequence.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to play a different game with one set of the cups. We're going to line them up from the one that makes the LOUDEST noise all the way to the one that makes the SOFTEST noise.

slides.prompt: Match all 6 pairs by sound. Then grade one set from loudest to softest. For an extra challenge: try matching with your eyes closed! Can your ears do it without your eyes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job listening and matching! You used your amazing ears to find sounds that are almost the same, and you even lined them up from loud to soft. That's like being a sound detective!

slides.text: 'Your ears are incredibly sensitive instruments! You can distinguish between sounds that are very similar. This skill helps you in music, in language, and in paying attention to the world around you.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 5 of 6 pairs and grade one set in order from loudest to softest?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job listening today! You learned that your ears are super special and can hear even tiny differences in sounds, which helps you learn all sorts of things, like music and talking!

parent_notes: Sound cylinders develop auditory discrimination — the ability to perceive subtle differences in sound. This is the same skill that underlies phonemic awareness in reading (hearing the difference between /b/ and /d/), musical pitch recognition, and attentive listening. The matching exercise requires the child to hold a sound in auditory memory while comparing it to other sounds — a demanding cognitive task. Work in silence; background noise interferes with this delicate work. The grading exercise (ordering from loudest to softest) develops the concept of seriation — arranging in a graduated order — which is a foundational mathematical concept. These cylinders were designed by Maria Montessori to isolate and refine a single sense.

title: Suffixes — Adding -ED and -S to Verbs
description: Building on the -ing suffix, the child learns that '-ed' makes a verb past tense (already happened) and '-s' makes it third person singular (he jumps). This expands the child's understanding of how suffixes change verb meaning and use.
instructions:
1. Review -ing: 'Adding -ing means it is happening NOW. Today we learn two MORE suffixes!'
2. Write 'jump' on the board. 'Jump + ed = JUMPED. The -ed means it ALREADY HAPPENED — in the past!'
3. Practice: walked, talked, helped, played, climbed, painted.
4. Note the three sounds of -ed: /t/ (walked), /d/ (played), /id/ (painted). 'The spelling is the same but the sound changes!'
5. Now -s: 'He jump + s = He JUMPS.' 'She reads. He runs. It works.'
6. Build a chart: jump / jumping / jumped / jumps.
